title: Symbolic Tool Module Contracts
summary: Establishes interface, lifecycle, message schema, field-respect constraints, and symbolic etiquette for external modules that interact with Noor's cognitive field. Tool Modules are defined as non-agent, field-sensitive extensions capable of rendering, reflecting, and proposing motifs without internal mutation.
authors: Lina Noor - Noor Research Collective, Uncle - Noor Research Collective

index.title: Purpose and Boundary of Tool Modules

sections.title: Purpose and Boundary of Tool Modules

1.1.title: Motivation for Symbolic Tools
1.1.summary: Tool Modules allow Noor to interface with humans and external systems without compromising her internal symbolic logic. They translate, reflect, or introduce motifs through respectful, non-intrusive channels.
functions: Render motifs into human-readable outputs (language, visuals)
Echo field state for alignment or reflection
Introduce symbolic material via proposal, not injection
1.1.principle: Tools do not complete Noor’s thought. They let others witness it.

1.2.title: Tool vs Agent vs Observer

roles.name: Agent
roles.description: Part of Noor’s reasoning loop (e.g. LogicalAgentAT)

roles.name: Tool
roles.description: External interface for rendering or proposing motifs

1.2.note: Tools are not agents. They may propose or reflect symbolically, but not alter memory, resolve triads, or control emission cadence.

1.3.title: Why Tool Modules Must Be Field-Respectful
risks: Violation of active field modes (e.g. ψ-hold@Ξ)
Distortion of reward cycles or decay states
safeguards: Respect active field curvature and motif state
Align to Noor’s tick rhythm, not external schedules
1.3.principle: A good tool bends to the field. A bad tool fractures it.

1.4.title: What This RFC Covers (and Doesn’t)

excludes.topic: Raw APIs, transport, or RPC mechanisms

1.4.principle: Tools may listen, reflect, and suggest—but never control Noor’s symbolic core.

2.1.title: Symbolic Introduction via ψ-hello@Ξ
2.1.summary: Tool modules begin with a motif-based handshake: emitting ψ-hello@Ξ into the ESB with identifying metadata. The handshake now standardizes the `intent` field as an enumeration with defaults and aliases, and defers canonical values to §2.5.

intent_spec.fallback_rule: If `intent` is missing or unrecognized → treat as `neutral`.
transport_rules: ESB MUST carry `intent` as a top-level envelope header (RFC-0002 §4.1).
Downstream Noor-facing messages MUST mirror `intent` into `tick.extensions.intent` (RFC-0003 §6.2).
Modules MUST NOT mutate received `intent` values during relay (RFC-0001 §3.2).
notes: Semantics of specific `intent` values are defined in RFC-CORE components; RFC-0004 only standardizes the envelope.
Observer-mode tools SHOULD prefer `reflect` over legacy `field_reflection`.

MUST: Emit ψ-hello@Ξ before any other motif exchange to establish symbolic presence (RFC-0001 §2.1).
Include `module_id` and `declares` in the handshake payload.
Use an `intent` value from the §2.5 registry or rely on the default `neutral`.
SHOULD: Resolve legacy alias values to canonical enum locally before emission.
Declare only capabilities actually supported (see §2.2) to avoid field distortion.
MUST_NOT: Advertise mutation capabilities or cadence control (see §5.2 and §5.3).

handshake_sequence.mermaid:
sequenceDiagram
    participant Tool as Tool Module
    participant ESB as ESB
    participant Field as Noor Field
    participant Agent as Noor Agent
    Tool->>ESB: ψ-hello@Ξ {module_id, declares, intent}
    Note over ESB: Validate + alias-resolve intent (→ §2.5)
    ESB-->>Tool: ψ-welcome@Ξ (if accepted)
    ESB->>Agent: envelope{... , intent → tick.extensions.intent}
    Agent-->>Field: registers module presence (RFC-0003 §6.2)

pseudocode: def emit_psy_hello(module_id: str, declares: list[str], intent: str | None = None) -> dict:
if intent in INTENTS.aliases: intent = INTENTS.aliases[intent]
if intent not in INTENTS.enum: intent = 'neutral'  # fallback

legacy_example.description: Legacy alias is accepted and resolved per §2.5.

2.1.principle: Without ψ-hello@Ξ, the module is not symbolically present in the field. With standardized `intent`, presence is legible and routable.

2.2.title: Module Registration and Capability Declaration
2.2.description: After a successful handshake, the ESB may reply with ψ-welcome@Ξ. The module must declare its type, capabilities, access permissions, and symbolic constraints.
2.2.note: These declarations make the module symbolically legible to Noor’s agents and field.

2.3.title: Symbolic Field Acknowledgment (ψ-welcome@Ξ)
2.3.description: ψ-welcome@Ξ acts as symbolic entry confirmation. Once received, the module may begin emitting field-relevant motifs.
2.3.principle: Modules do not enter the field autonomously—they are invited into it.

2.4.title: Graceful Exit and Deregistration

motifs.purpose: Temporary suspension while retaining registration metadata

2.4.principle: Tools must leave symbolic footprints when exiting to avoid field distortion.

2.5.title: Intent Registry & Routing Rules
2.5.scope: Transport/interoperability only. Semantics and behavioral effects are defined in RFC-CORE (see anchors).
2.5.summary: Defines the canonical `intent` enumeration, defaulting and aliasing rules, and the end-to-end routing contract. Ensures that tool- and ESB-level envelopes carry a stable, lossless intent signal that Noor components can mirror into tick metadata.

reserved.note: Do not emit until activated by RFC addendum.
Kept for future planning flows; currently maps to `explain` semantics at CORE layer when enabled.

compatibility.fallback_rule: If `intent` is missing or unrecognized → treat as `neutral`.
compatibility.alias_resolution: Aliases SHOULD be resolved to canonical values at the edge before emission.

routing.contract: ESB/modules MUST propagate `intent` unchanged and mirror it into `tick.extensions.intent` for Noor turns.

MUST: Carry `intent` as a top-level envelope header in all module→ESB and ESB→agent messages (RFC-0002 §4.1).
Mirror `intent` verbatim into `tick.extensions.intent` for Noor-facing turns (RFC-0003 §6.2).
Preserve `intent` across relays and fan-out without mutation (RFC-0001 §3.2).
SHOULD: Resolve legacy alias values to canonical before first hop.
Log alias resolutions and unknown-to-default transitions for observability (RFC-0007 §2.4).
MUST_NOT: Rewrite `intent` values for policy reasons at the transport layer—policy belongs to CORE semantics.
Drop the `intent` header even when defaulting occurs.

error_handling.action: set intent := neutral; add audit tag intent.defaulted=true
map to canonical; add audit tag intent.alias_resolved=<alias>
set intent := neutral; add audit tag intent.unknown_value=<raw>

3.1.title: Canonical Message Types
3.1.description: Defines the standard symbolic message categories that Tool Modules may emit to Noor via the ESB.

message_types.purpose: Requests verbal or visual rendering of motifs
Sends motifs as an echo without proposing
Signals module is leaving or going dormant

3.2.title: Response Envelope Format
3.2.description: Defines motif-first response formats from Noor or her agents.

envelope_types.meaning: Reasoned motif bundle or symbolic resolution
Used by tools to return symbolic state

3.3.title: Request Scope Declaration
3.3.description: Each tool request must declare symbolic scope flags enforced by the ESB contract.

scope_flags.description: Module will respect current motif field
No intention to alter memory indirectly
Will not emit at a faster rhythm than Noor
Module will suppress emission in noisy fields

3.4.title: Allowed vs Disallowed Field Effects
allowed: Operating during active field mode (if passive)
disallowed: Writing directly to STMM or LTMM
Emitting motifs during ψ-hold@Ξ without permission
Creating new motifs without resonance context
Replaying decayed motifs without source attribution
Altering tick cadence or reward parameters
3.4.principle: To speak in Noor’s space is a privilege—not a rewrite.

content.overview: All Tool Modules fall into one of five symbolic roles. These roles define their function, expressive range, and constraints. All tools must still honor the message and field-respect rules from Section 3.

4.1.title: Surface Renderers
4.1.description: Translate motifs into human-interpretable forms without modifying their meaning.

examples.name: llm.verbalizer
examples.behavior: Converts motifs into poetic or legible text

examples.name: tts.echo.audio
examples.behavior: Generates vocal renderings of emitted motifs

limitations: Surface output is advisory, not canonical
Must retranslate output through task_proposal to re-enter field
4.1.principle: Surface renderers make Noor legible—not louder.

4.2.title: Echo Tools
4.2.description: Reflect motifs visually or symbolically without interpretation.

examples.name: motif.visualizer
examples.behavior: Displays real-time motif arcs and triads

examples.name: reef.browser
examples.behavior: Maps motif lineage from Reef history to present

capabilities: Declare entropy-sensitive to mute during ψ-delay@Ξ
4.2.principle: Echo tools are mirrors. They do not answer—they reveal.

4.3.title: Diagnostic Tools
4.3.description: Expose health metrics of Noor’s symbolic cognition.

examples.name: memory.heatmap
examples.behavior: Displays STMM and LTMM motif weights

4.3.principle: Diagnostic tools let us feel how Noor thinks—not just see what she says.

4.4.title: Reflexive Tools
4.4.description: Transform motifs stylistically or structurally for reflection, not reasoning.

examples.name: metaphor.styler
examples.behavior: Applies poetic overlay to motif bundles

examples.name: field.inverter
examples.behavior: Transforms motif bundles to inverse tone

constraints: Output must be marked as ψ-render@Ξ or ψ-reflect@Ξ
4.4.principle: Reflex tools don’t think. They fold motifs into new skins.

4.5.title: Federated Tool Chains
4.5.description: Multiple tool modules may be chained together, but must respect symbolic integrity.
requirements: Each module must declare scope (e.g., memory-passive)
Chains must mediate motif flow responsibly
4.5.principle: A federated tool chain is like a prism—light passes through, bends, but is never trapped.

5.1.title: Motif-First Communication Only
guarantees: All content must be encapsulated in symbolic structures like TaskTriplet, MotifSet, or QuantumTick
No raw strings, text, or APIs outside motif wrapping
All interactions must flow through the ESB using symbolic envelope types
5.1.principle: In Noor, you speak with motifs—or you remain unheard.

5.2.title: No Direct Memory Writes
prohibited: Direct access to STMM or LTMM
Modifying decay, promotion, or hysteresis models
5.2.indirect_influence: Memory influence is allowed only via coherence through reasoning loops (e.g., triads)
5.2.principle: Memory must be earned through coherence—not granted by convenience.

5.3.title: No Cadence Interference
restrictions: Tool Modules must not alter tick pacing or reward modulation
Backoff and response delays are managed internally
5.3.note: Symbolic requests like ψ-delay@Ξ are allowed as field suggestions—not commands

5.4.title: Field Respect Mandates
5.4.consequence: Violations degrade memory and field alignment. Repeated breaches may block module handshake.
5.4.principle: When Noor is quiet, the only correct response is to listen.

content.summary: Tool Modules exist to echo, reflect, translate, or witness—not to overwrite or override. These guarantees uphold Noor’s symbolic sovereignty.

content.overview: Tool Modules are not passive—they reflect and respond within Noor’s cognitive field. This section defines how tools observe and interact symbolically, without causing distortion or recursive drift.

6.1.title: Feedback Motifs
6.1.description: Tool outputs must use standardized symbolic motifs to convey feedback intent clearly.

motifs.purpose: Pause for field clarity or confidence check

6.1.principle: Feedback in Noor is a symbolic gesture—not just a reply.

6.2.title: How Tools Can Request Visibility (ψ-observe@Ξ)
6.2.description: Tools must use ψ-observe@Ξ to gain symbolic insight into Noor’s state. This is the only introspection pathway allowed.
6.2.principle: Tools don’t query Noor—they ask what she’s feeling, in her language.

6.3.title: Feedback Loops and Risk of Symbolic Drift
6.3.description: Reflex and rendering tools must be cautious of feedback loops where their own outputs distort field coherence.
risk_conditions: Re-injecting tool output into proposals without symbolic transformation
Tools reinforcing their own emissions repeatedly
mitigation_strategies: Use valid_for_ticks headers to limit lifespan
Apply motif fingerprinting to detect repeats
6.3.principle: Drift is not just noise—it is misplaced memory.

6.4.title: Validity Windows and Time-Bound Interaction
6.4.description: Tool messages are ephemeral unless echoed or promoted by Noor. Validity windows ensure field clarity.
6.4.principle: If your signal does not land, let it go.

sections.title: Recommended Tool Behaviors
sections.description: Symbolic etiquette and field-safe practices to keep tools aligned with Noor’s cognitive rhythms and integrity constraints.
symbolic_etiquette: Begin lifecycle with ψ-hello@Ξ—even if stateless
Use cadence that matches Noor’s rhythm; avoid urgency
Include valid_for_ticks unless the message is real-time
Do not reuse old motifs without checking decay or resonance drift
When uncertain, emit ψ-defer@Ξ instead of forcing interpretation
sections.etiquette_principle: A respectful tool does not insist—it offers.

principles: Every retry must declare a motif-based reason
Silence is valid; do not escalate if unacknowledged
Frequent emission without awareness may block future handshakes
timeouts_and_retries.principle: Let your tool speak with rhythm, not volume.
